Russian President Vladimir Putin on Monday declared a unilateral three-day ceasefire in Ukraine next month, a move met with skepticism by Ukrainian officials who demanded the Kremlin leader immediately accept a longer truce proposal from the United States that he has so far rejected.

Moscow said ‚Äúall military actions‚Äù in Ukraine would be suspended from midnight May 8 to midnight May 11, a decision which it said was based on ‚Äúhumanitarian considerations.‚Äù The truce would coincide with Russia‚Äôs World War II Victory Day commemorations on May 9 and the 80th anniversary of the defeat of Nazi Germany.

Putin‚Äôs announcement ‚Äì which was met with renewed urging from the White House for a ‚Äúpermanent ceasefire‚Äù ‚Äì comes as the Trump administration ramps up pressure on Moscow and Kyiv to agree to a deal to end the war.

On Sunday, US Secretary of State Marco Rubio said this week would be ‚Äúvery critical‚Äù in determining whether the US would persist with its efforts to broker peace.

‚ÄúWhile President Trump welcomes Vladimir Putin‚Äôs willingness to pause the conflict, the president has been very clear he wants a permanent ceasefire and to bring this conflict to a peaceful resolution,‚Äù US National Security Council Spokesman Brian Hughes said on Monday.

Later on Monday, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky called the ceasefire declaration an ‚Äúattempt at manipulation,‚Äù pointing out that, despite the Kremlin leader saying he wants peace, he has not accepted the US proposal for a 30-day ceasefire that Kyiv has agreed to.

‚ÄúRussia has consistently rejected everything and continues to manipulate the world, trying to deceive the United States. Now, yet again, another attempt at manipulation: for some reason everyone is supposed to wait until May 8 before ceasing fire ‚Äì just to provide Putin with silence for his parade,‚Äù Zelensky said in apost on X.

Zelensky‚Äôs chief of staff Andriy Yermak thanked Trump on Monday for ‚Äúsupporting a full ceasefire,‚Äù writing in apost on Xthat ‚Äúonly a permanent, unconditional, and comprehensive ceasefire ‚Äì not a temporary one, as Putin proposes ‚Äì is necessary to end the war.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf Russia truly wants peace, it must cease fire immediately,‚Äù Ukrainian Foreign Minister Andrii Sybiha said in response to Monday‚Äôs announcement from the Kremlin. ‚ÄúWhy wait until May 8th?‚Äù

‚ÄúUkraine is ready to support a lasting, durable, and full ceasefire. And this is what we are constantly proposing, for at least 30 days,‚Äù he added.

The announcement came a little more than a week after the Kremlin proclaimed a30-hour truceover Easter, which Kyiv cautiously agreed to. Ukraine‚Äôs military later accused Russia of violating that April 19 ceasefire with more than 2,900 attacks along the expansive frontlines. Moscow also accused Ukraine of repeatedly breaking that truce.

Monitoring group the Institute for the Study of War said Putin was refusing ‚Äúany ceasefire other than on terms that advantage his war effort.‚Äù

‚ÄùÔªøRussian forces seized on the Easter ceasefire to shell and conduct reconnaissance of frontline Ukrainian positions and damaged vehicles along the frontline in preparation for future Russian assaults, and Russian forces will likely use the Victory Day ceasefire for similar preparatory efforts,‚Äù the US-based think tank said in its latest assessment.

Senior Trump administration officials say the coming weeks will be a pivotal time in negotiating an end to the war, more than three years after Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre close, but we‚Äôre not close enough,‚ÄùRubio saidon NBC‚Äôs ‚ÄúMeet the Press‚Äù on Sunday, following a phone call with Russia‚Äôs Foreign Minster Sergey Lavrov.

Moscow described a ‚Äúproductive exchange of views‚Äù between the two.

US President Donald Trump has voiced increasing frustration over the failed efforts to broker a peace agreement within his self-imposed target of the first 100 days of his presidency.On Sunday, Trump leveled pointed criticism at Putin in some of his most potent comments to date, urging his Russian counterpart to ‚Äústop shooting, sit down and sign a deal.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe have the confines of a deal, I believe, and I want him to sign it and be done with it and just go back to life,‚Äù Trump said.

Trump‚Äôs comments came after he returned to Washington following a trip to Pope Francis‚Äô funeral at the Vatican on Saturday. He met Zelensky on the sidelines of the ceremony for a short talk that both sides described as productive.

Since April 19, when Putin proclaimed the temporary Easter ceasefire, Russian attacks have killed at least 62 civilians and injured another 290 in Ukraine, according to a CNN tally of figures from local authorities and emergency services.

‚ÄúThe Easter ceasefire has already shown that there was no ceasefire in reality,‚Äù a senior officer in Ukraine‚Äôs Security Service (SBU), who goes by the call sign Bankir and has been fighting in the Zaporizhzhia region, told CNN on Monday.

‚ÄúThere were a lot of enemy drones and artillery continued to work without reducing the intensity,‚Äù Bankir reflected. ‚ÄúThe Easter ceasefire showed that it was just public statements that were not confirmed in practice.‚Äù

Russian PresidentVladimir Putinhas declared a temporary ceasefire in Ukraine to time with its "Victory Day" commemorations marking 80 years since the defeat of the Nazis and the end of World War II.

The Kremlin said the truce is "based on humanitarian considerations" and will last from the passing of midnight on May 7 into May 8, until the passing of midnight on May 10 into May 11.

"For this period, all hostilities are stopped," said the statement. "Russia believes that the Ukrainian side should follow suit. In the event of violations of the ceasefire by the Ukrainian side, the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation will give an adequate and effective response."

Newsweekreached out to the State Department and Ukraine's presidential office for comment.

The declaration of a truce comes as U.S. PresidentDonald TrumpcriticizesRussia and Putin directly‚Äîa rare rebuke‚Äîfor the ongoing strikes in Ukraine. He urged Putin to "STOP" on Truth Social and said he found Russian actions "very disappointing."

His tone on Ukrainian PresidentVolodymyr Zelenskyalso warmed following their face-to-face meeting at the Vatican duringPope Francis's funeral.

Trump has threatened to walk away from the peace process unless good progress is made quickly. He believes the sides are close to a deal and should hold high-level direct talks to get an agreement over the line.

U.S. Secretary of StateMarco Rubiosaid Sunday that this week would be "very critical." The U.S. needs to "make a determination about whether this is an endeavor that we want to continue to be involved in," he said onNBC'sMeet the Press.

The Kremlin added in its statement on a truce that it "once again declares its readiness for peace talks without preconditions, aimed at eliminating the root causes of the Ukrainian crisis, constructive interaction with international partners."

Up until now, Putin had refused to accept a complete, unconditional ceasefire, linking it to a halt in Western arms supplies to Ukraine and Ukraine's mobilization effort.

Just before the ceasefire announcement, Ukraine and Russiatargeted each other with long-range strikes.

The Russian Defense Ministry said its forces downed 119 Ukrainian drones overnight, most of them over Russia's Bryansk border region.

In Ukraine, air raid sirens sounded across the country on Monday morning. There were no immediate reports of casualties or damage.

Putin had previously declared a unilateral 30-hour Easter truce, a move the Ukrainians said shows peace is in Russia's hands. Both sides accused each other of firing during Putin's Easter truce.

Zelenskyhas said previouslythat Ukraine wants "an immediate, full, and unconditional ceasefire."

"This is absolutely possible‚Äìbut only if Russia agrees and stops the killing," Zelensky wrote in an April 23 post on X, formerlyTwitter. He added: "Ukraine has repeatedly said that it does not rule out any format that can lead to a ceasefire and, ultimately, real peace."

Ukrainian President Zelenskyposted on X after his Vatican meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump:"Good meeting. We discussed a lot one on one. Hoping for results on everything we covered. Protecting lives of our people. Full and unconditional ceasefire. Reliable and lasting peace that will prevent another war from breaking out. Very symbolic meeting that has potential to become historic, if we achieve joint results. Thank you @POTUS."

Ukraine has not said if it would also adhere to Putin's latest declaration of a truce. However, Ukraine's foreign minister Andrii Sybiha questioned why a ceasefire could not be immediate. He said Ukraine would agree to an immediate truce for 30 days.
